results.abstract: Astronauts Lt Col Edward Mike Fincke and Col Gennadi I Padalka succeed in second attempt to make needed repairs to International Space Station gyroscope (M)

headline.main: Astronauts Complete Spacewalk, Using Russian and U.S. Gear

results.snippet: The two astronauts manning the International Space Station left their orbiting outpost on Wednesday and succeeded in their second attempt to replace a failed circuit breaker and restore use of a critical steering gyroscope.     The American and...
results.lead_paragraph: The two astronauts manning the International Space Station left their orbiting outpost on Wednesday and succeeded in their second attempt to replace a failed circuit breaker and restore use of a critical steering gyroscope. The American and Russian astronauts finished their main task an hour earlier than scheduled after crossing a broad expanse of the spacecraft to complete a job cut short last Thursday because of a malfunctioning space suit.

results.abstract: Independence Day is celebrated at beaches, backyards and parks across New York metropolitan area, culminating in Macy's Fourth of July fireworks display on East River; security across region is tight but relatively unobtrusive; photos (M)

headline.main: A Brilliant Sky, and Muted Security; Fun, Solemn, Safety-Conscious: A Hundred Americas

results.snippet: They paraded up Main Street in the old patriot towns, drumming the cadence and flying the colors. They thronged beaches, baseball stands and quiet parks. They barbecued in backyards, strolled down country lanes and gathered on village greens to hear...

byline.original: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN; Reporting for this article was contributed by Stacy Albin, Eddy Ramirez, Colin Moynihan, Howard O. Stier and Karen DeMasters

results.lead_paragraph: They paraded up Main Street in the old patriot towns, drumming the cadence and flying the colors. They thronged beaches, baseball stands and quiet parks. They barbecued in backyards, strolled down country lanes and gathered on village greens to hear the Declaration of Independence read once more. America -- a hundred Americas -- found expression yesterday across the New York metropolitan area on a soft and sunny Fourth of July filled with ceremony, celebration, security and old-fashioned fun. Bikers, joggers, picnickers and sunbathers were out in force, and there were concerts, music festivals, walking tours and countless gatherings of families and friends.

results.abstract: Andrian Nikolayev, Russian astronaut whose flight into space in 1962 set endurance record at the time, dies at age 74 (S)
results.snippet: Andrian Nikolayev, whose flight into space in 1962 set an endurance record at the time, died Saturday in Cheboksary, the capital of his birthplace, the Chuvash Autonomous Republic. He was 74.    Mr. Nikolayev had a heart attack while judging the All...
results.lead_paragraph: Andrian Nikolayev, whose flight into space in 1962 set an endurance record at the time, died Saturday in Cheboksary, the capital of his birthplace, the Chuvash Autonomous Republic. He was 74. Mr. Nikolayev had a heart attack while judging the All Russian Rural Sport Games in Cheboksary and died at a hospital there, the Interfax news agency reported.

results.abstract: Voters in Mongolia cut governing party's numbers in 76-seat Parliament from 72 to 36; opposition party claims to have won two more seats, and has taken its argument to administrative court; Pres Bush is expected to hail Mongolia's multiparty democracy when he receives Pres Natsagiyn Bagabandi in Washington, but China is viewing development somewhat differently; Western reporters flocked to Mongolia to cover its revolution through ballot box, but editors in China stayed away and Chinese newspapers, magazines and television have largely kept silent about results; photo; map (M)

headline.main: A Cunning Opposition Turns Tables in Mongolia

results.snippet: Voters in this literate, sparsely populated country between China and Russia have handed their governing party of former Communists an uncommon lesson that indicates that a young democracy may have come of age.     In a boisterous election 10 days...
results.lead_paragraph: Voters in this literate, sparsely populated country between China and Russia have handed their governing party of former Communists an uncommon lesson that indicates that a young democracy may have come of age. In a boisterous election 10 days ago that pitted guile against might, the country's 1.5 million voters cut the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party numbers in the 76-seat Parliament from 72 to 36. On Wednesday, the General Election Commission confirmed that the opposition, the Motherland Democratic Coalition, known as the Democrats, won 34 seats. The Democrats claim to have won two more seats, and have taken their argument to an administrative court. They are also wooing three independents in the hope of forming a government.

results.abstract: Mayor Michael Bloomberg goes to Queens to honor Indian-American astronaut Kalpana Chawla, who was killed in explosion of space shuttle Columbia; he describes how he walked with Chawla in annual Indian Day Parade last year; mayoral aide later explains that Bloomberg had actually walked in parade with another Indian-American astronaut, Sunita L Williams, and had gotten two astronauts mixed up (S)

headline.main: Mayor's Sentiments Were Right, if the Astronaut Wasn't

results.snippet: As mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg attends many memorial ceremonies for strangers. But yesterday, when he visited Queens to honor an Indian-American astronaut killed in the explosion of the space shuttle Columbia, Mr. Bloomberg made a point of noting...
results.lead_paragraph: As mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg attends many memorial ceremonies for strangers. But yesterday, when he visited Queens to honor an Indian-American astronaut killed in the explosion of the space shuttle Columbia, Mr. Bloomberg made a point of noting that this time was different. In elaborate detail, the mayor described how he had walked ''30 to 40 blocks'' with the astronaut, Kalpana Chawla, at the annual Indian Day Parade last year, talking along the way about many subjects.

results.abstract: Excerpts from interview with Sacha Baron Cohen, British comic and star of Da Ali G Show, which is set to begin its second season on HBO; photo (M)

headline.main: The Cheerful Confessions Of Ali G, Borat And Bruno

results.snippet: ''Da Ali G Show,'' the British comic Sacha Baron Cohen's stunningly funny HBO series, returns for its second American season on Sunday.     While playing the part of Ali G, an imbecilic and gonzo rapper who speaks in Caribbean-British slang, Mr....
results.lead_paragraph: ''Da Ali G Show,'' the British comic Sacha Baron Cohen's stunningly funny HBO series, returns for its second American season on Sunday. While playing the part of Ali G, an imbecilic and gonzo rapper who speaks in Caribbean-British slang, Mr. Baron Cohen in the first few episodes interviews Pat Buchanan, Sam Donaldson and Gore Vidal. For all the publicity that Ali G received in his initial HBO season, in which he put on the likes of Newt Gingrich, the former astronaut Edwin E. Aldrin Jr. and the former director of central intelligence R. James Woolsey, none of this season's august figures managed to see their disguised interviewer for who he is: a wickedly smart, left-wing comedian and practicing Jew with a degree from Cambridge.

results.abstract: Long Island Journal column; former astronaut Fred Haise and other VIP's, surrounded by children attending space camp at Cradle of Aviation Museum in East Garden City, help count down to 35th anniversary of launch of Apollo 11; tryouts are held at Roosevelt Field mall, part of local mall star search for chance to sing Star-Spangled Banner at Mets game in fall; photo (M)

headline.main: When the Island Took the Ride to the Moon

results.snippet: WITH a toy rocket set to launch and a Tang toast, Fred Haise, a former astronaut, counted down last weekend to the 35th anniversary of the launch of Apollo 11.    Surrounded by children attending space camp, it took one small step for Mr. Haise, 70,...
results.lead_paragraph: WITH a toy rocket set to launch and a Tang toast, Fred Haise, a former astronaut, counted down last weekend to the 35th anniversary of the launch of Apollo 11. Surrounded by children attending space camp, it took one small step for Mr. Haise, 70, to stomp on a plastic pedal and propel a foam rocket toward the ceiling of the Cradle of Aviation Museum in East Garden City. But it took a giant leap in the 1960's by dedicated engineers and technicians at Grumman Aircraft Corporation in Bethpage to build the lunar excursion modules that ferried man to the moon.

results.abstract: Consumed article by Rob Walker on new line of mens' personal-care products by startup called Sharps that tries to elude macho man vs peacock dichotomy that has long dominated; notes various marketing campaigns in $1-billion-plus industry (M)

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 7-25-04: CONSUMED

results.snippet: Sharps  A recently published book called ''The Male Mystique'' offers a collection of ads from men's magazines of the 60's and 70's. Among other things, it makes a convincing case that the marketer's construction of manhood has been conflicted and...
results.lead_paragraph: Sharps A recently published book called ''The Male Mystique'' offers a collection of ads from men's magazines of the 60's and 70's. Among other things, it makes a convincing case that the marketer's construction of manhood has been conflicted and simpleminded for a long time: macho oafs, shameless peacocks and the interchangeable ''groovy'' chicks who love them fill out pitches for Bacchus after-shave, Score Liquid Hair Groom and something called Male Comfort Spray (which ''helps prevent perspiration discomfort, the kind only a man can get''). That stuff, whatever it was, seems mercifully to have faded from the scene. Men's grooming products are now a $1-billion-plus category, with a snowballing number of new offerings. But the marketing dichotomy lingers in the form of two caricatures of maleness: the ''Queer Eye for the Straight Guy'' guy vs. the Maxim guy. Still, one new brand, a small New York startup called Sharps, seems almost explicitly designed as an attempt to find a third way. Though around only since last year, it has found its way into top-end retailers like Barneys and Fred Segal, as well as newish boutique barbershop chains like American Male. One of its most popular items, called Kid Glove Shave Gel, is a top seller at the Barneys in Beverly Hills. Through Sharps's online store, it sells to customers in all but a handful of states, thanks to attention from magazines like InStyle and Men's Health.

results.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews movie Thunderbirds, directed by Jonathan Frakes and starring Bill Paxton and Brady Corbet; photo (M)

headline.main: Space Age Hero Kids, Halting Evil Frantically

results.snippet: ''Thunderbirds'' wants to be two things at once: a live-action gee-whiz kiddie flick in the style of the ''Spy Kids'' movies and a nostalgic spoof of England in the 1960's, when it swung like a pendulum.    If the two concepts don't really mesh, the...
results.lead_paragraph: ''Thunderbirds'' wants to be two things at once: a live-action gee-whiz kiddie flick in the style of the ''Spy Kids'' movies and a nostalgic spoof of England in the 1960's, when it swung like a pendulum. If the two concepts don't really mesh, the film, directed by Jonathan Frakes, maintains the frantic, fractured momentum of a Saturday morning cartoon as its heroes, the Tracys, a squeaky-clean clan of space-age goody-goods, do battle with the Hood (Ben Kingsley), a greedy glowering villain with a chip on his shoulder. Hood, whose malevolent gaze unleashes telekinetic powers, plans to hijack the Tracys' 21st-century technology to rob the world's 10 largest banks, starting with the Bank of England.
